results.name: Outlaws and the end
results.description: Tracing connections from Sweet Country to Australian westerns and resistance to white colonial narratives.

key_work.title: Set design in Sweet Country
key_work.brief_description: Australian western set on the Northern Territory frontier in the 1920s, where justice itself is put on trial when an aged Aboriginal farmhand shoots a white man in self-defense and goes on the run as a posse gathers to hunt him down.

constellations_primary.description: Tracing connections from Sweet Country to Australian westerns and resistance to white colonial narratives.

constellations_other.description: Robert Connolly's The Dry is a recent Australian crime blockbuster, but the writer, director and producer's first film (and first crime film) connects to a longstanding tradition of true-blue crime stories from some of our greatest filmmakers.

end.title: We Don't Need a Map
end.creator_credit: Warwick Thornton, Brendan Fletcher and Barefoot Communications
end.brief_description: Filmmaker Warwick Thornton investigates our relationship to the Southern Cross, in this fun and thought provoking ride through Australia’s cultural and political landscape.

constellations_other.name: Outlaws and the end
constellations_other.description: Tracing connections from Sweet Country to Australian westerns and resistance to white colonial narratives.

links.description: In Sweet Country, an Indigenous man suffers racist violence from a white WWI veteran. The Southern Cross tattoo, like war, is seen as part of white Australian identity but is now associated with racism. In Thornton’s doco, he reclaims the constellation and its ties to Indigenous culture.

start.title: The Proposition
start.creator_credit: Cat Villiers, Chiara Menage, Chris Brown, Christopher Simon, Jackie O'Sullivan, Pam Collis and Chris Kennedy
start.brief_description: Set in the Australian outback in the 1880s, the movie follows the series of events following the horrific rape and murder of the Hopkins family, allegedly committed by the infamous Burns brothers gang. Captain Morris Stanley captures Charlie Burns and gives him 9 days to kill his older dangerous psychopathic brother, or else they’ll hang his younger mentally slow brother on Christmas Day.

end.title: Tilly Dunnage's (Kate Winslet) black and bronze dress from The Dressmaker
end.credit_line: Courtesy The National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
end.brief_description:
This dress reflects Tilly’s character as a strong, practical and hardworking person. The fabric has a metallic sheen that is reminiscent of armour. Tilly rarely lets her guard down and continues to endure immense hardship fighting the constant attacks of the townsfolk. The costume shows Tilly’s serious side, and its darker tones perhaps reflect the underlying darkness that drives her story.

Designer Margot Wilson was solely responsible for creating Tilly’s (Kate Winslet) wardrobe, and they collaborated closely to get the best fit and style. This dress is perfectly tailored to Winslet’s form. It showcases the meticulous craftsmanship needed to make the highly structured and figure-defining designs of early 1950s European couture.

constellations_other.name: Outlaws and the end

links.description: This costume from The Dressmaker has a metallic sheen reminiscent of armour. It reflects Tilly’s (Kate Winslet) strength. Designer Margot Wilson also did the costumes for western, The Proposition. Fitting as The Dressmaker director Jocelyn Moorehouse likened the film to famous western, “Unforgiven with a sewing machine.”

links.description: The art of Foley is named after Jack Foley, who started out making live sound effects for radio. He later transferred his audio trickery to films, including on Spartacus, where he created the sound of an army on horseback using a set of keys.

constellations_other.description: Visual artists have identified the importance of light in revealing the expansiveness of our universe. Explore how artists’ perception of light has been adapted and referenced in science fiction and fantasy on screen.

constellations_other.name: Sound and cinema
constellations_other.description: Beginning with one of the first films to be screened at the Palais (a Melbourne cinema with its own outstanding resident orchestra) the constellation celebrates sound as an integral part of the connection between moving image work and audience.

constellations_other.name: Innovation, technology and design: Edweard Muybridge
constellations_other.description: A focus on the discovery, inspiration and innovation at the heart of moving image history

constellations_other.name: Found footage and the first camcorder
constellations_other.description: Amateur filmmakers turned the camera on their own lives when camcorders like the Sony Betamovie BMC-100P came on the market. The style of footage filmed on camcorders has inspired many fictional films, particularly in the horror genre.

constellations_other.name: One of the first auteurs
constellations_other.description: A progenitor of modern film genres such as sci-fi, psychological thriller and serial killer films decades before such terms were coined, Austrian-born director Fritz Lang also enjoyed the occasional on-screen meta-moment.

links.description: Foley artists on classic films like Spartacus were never credited, making it hard to trace a history of the craft. One of the first people to be credited for making sound effects for a film is Benjamin Burtt Jr for Star Wars, but it would be decades before all Foley artists were regularly credited for their work.

links.description: The sound of laser blasters in Star Wars is so iconic that many Star Wars cast members now have difficulty not making ‘pew pew’ noises themselves while filming. In fact, Laura Dern can be seen in the finished cut of The Last Jedi mouthing ‘pew’ while firing her blaster.

links.description: Tacita Dean’s installation artwork features the work of sound effects creator Beryl Mortimer, known in the industry as ‘Beryl The Boot’ for her ability to mimic footsteps. results.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
results.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

key_work.title: English mahogany and brass bi-unial magic lantern
key_work.brief_description: The magic lantern is an important ancestor of cinema. Developed in the 1600s, magic lanterns use a light source, lenses and transparent slides to project religious, educational or entertaining scenes and stories. Bi-unial lanterns use two lenses to create the illusion of movement.

key_work.title: Storyboarding in Ten Canoes
key_work.brief_description: Filmed in Arnhem Land with a cast of local Indigenous Australians, Ten Canoes interweaves two tales of forbidden love and consequence, spanning thousands of years of Yolngu storytelling, and is told entirely in language.

start.title: Moonlight
start.creator_credit: Adele Romanski, Dede Gardner, Jeremy Kleiner, Altitude Film Entertainment and PASTEL
start.brief_description: The tender, heartbreaking story of a young man’s struggle to find himself, told across three defining chapters in his life as he experiences the ecstasy, pain, and beauty of falling in love, while grappling with his own sexuality.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance

end.title: Three Times
end.creator_credit: Chang Hua-Fu, Huang Wen-Ying and Liao Ching-Sung
end.brief_description: There are three stories of women and men. In the first two stories, letters are crucial to the outcome; in the third, it’s cell-phone calls, text messages, and a computer file. Over the years between the tales, as sexual intimacy becomes more likely and words more free, communication recedes.

links.description: Moonlight‘s structure, crossing the boundaries of three different time periods was inspired by Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-hsien’s aptly-named 2005 film Three Times.

start.title: The Tracker
start.creator_credit: Julie Ryan and Vertigo Productions
start.brief_description: Somewhere in Australia in the early 20th century outback, an Aboriginal man is accused of murdering a white woman. Three white men are on a mission to capture him with the help of an experienced Indigenous man.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

start.creator_credit: Sarah Radclyffe, Channel 4 Television and Derek Jarman
start.brief_description: As influential Italian artist Caravaggio dies in exile in 1610, he recalls his short life, from his childhood to his initial artistic failures to his later triumphs as he catches the eye of a sympathetic cardinal to his destructive relationship with a dashing gambler.

links.description: In Derek Jarman’s biopic Caravaggio, the artist’s work is described by Giovanni Baglione as “unbearable, a fingernail scratched along a blackboard”, a dig at film critic Vincent Canby who used the same line about Jarman’s adaptation of The Tempest.

start.title: The Tempest
start.creator_credit: Jason K. Lau, Julia Taylor-Stanley, Julie Taymor, Lynn Hendee and Robert Chartoff
start.brief_description: An adaptation of the play by William Shakespeare. Prospera (a female version of Shakespeare’s Prospero) is the usurped ruler of Milan who has been banished to a mysterious island with her daughter. Using her magical powers, she draws her enemies to the island to exact her revenge.

end.title: Shakespeare in Love
end.creator_credit: David Parfitt, Donna Gigliotti, Edward Zwick, Harvey Weinstein and Marc Norman
end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 1998
end.brief_description: Young Shakespeare is forced to stage his latest comedy, “Romeo and Ethel, the Pirate’s Daughter,” before it’s even written. When a lovely noblewoman auditions for a role, they fall into forbidden love — and his play finds a new life (and title). As their relationship progresses, Shakespeare’s comedy soon transforms into tragedy.

links.description: Sandy Powell went from designing costumes from a film about Shakespeare, to a film (based on a play) written by Shakespeare.

links.description: These are both crime films based on news reports of true stories. Dog Day Afternoon is based on a LIFE magazine article called ‘The Boys in the Bank’, while Hustlers is based on ‘The Hustlers at Scores’, which appeared in New York magazine.

start.title: Sweet Country
start.creator_credit: Warwick Thornton, Heather Wallace, David Jowsey, Greer Simpkin, Bunya Productions, Tony Cronin, David Tranter and Steven McGregor
start.brief_description: It’s 1929 on the vast, desert-like, Eastern Arrernte Nation lands that are now known as the Central Australian outback. Sam Kelly, a middle-aged Aboriginal man, works the land of a kind preacher, Fred Smith. After an ill-tempered bully arrives in town and Kelly kills him in self-defence, he and his wife go on the run as a posse gathers to hunt him down.

constellations_primary.name: Sweet Country
constellations_primary.description: Warwick Thornton’s feature film Sweet Country is based on the story of Wilaberta Jack, which was told to sound recordist David Tranter by his grandfather and translated into storyboards.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

end.title: Raumlichtkunst
end.creator_credit: Oskar Fischinger
end.credit_line:
Oskar Fischinger

Three-screen installation

Reconstruction by Center for Visual Music, USA
end.brief_description: Oskar Fischinger’s Raumlichtkunst is one of the first multimedia projections ever made. Using film projectors, colour filters and slides, Fischinger staged multi-screen film events that were first shown in Germany around 1926 and reconstructed by the Center for Visual Music (CVM) in Los Angeles.

constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

links.description: Oskar Fischinger staged some of the very first multi-media performances in history. Raumlichtkunst, a reconstruction of his multiple-screen film events, first shown in Germany in 1926, was restored by the Center for Visual Music (CVM) in Los Angeles and shows in Gallery 2.

end.title: Lichtspiel: Opus I
end.brief_description: Against a dark background, several bright, curved or rounded shapes pulse towards the center of the screen, one at a time. They are followed by many other shapes, some irregular, some pointed, others rounded. The abstract shapes move into or across the screen in harmony with the musical score.

links.description: Just as Taree McKenzie explores colour in abstraction, Walter Ruttman’s Lichtspiel Opus I also uses colour without reference to any representational imagery. This was the first abstract film to be publicly screened.

end.title: Hue
end.brief_description:
Hue is a stark puzzle platformer where you shift the hue of the world, creating rifts when colours collide.

In this world, everyone sees in grayscale. Anne, a researcher specialising in colour theory, has created a mysterious ring which grants the ability to perceive and alter colour. After a fracas with her research assistant, she disappears into a coloured void. You play as Hue, Anne’s son, as he discovers fragments of his missing mother’s research and learns to perceive and alter colour for the first time.

constellations_other.name: Colour and illusion
constellations_other.description: Exploring the science of colour, light, reflection and movement.

links.description: This focus on colour as something with its own character and magical qualities inspired the videogame Hue where a grayscale world becomes transformed through the discovery of colour and its capacity for transformation.

links.description: In Lichtspiel, animated colours move to a musical score. For artist Oskar Fischinger, colour has the ability to create its own visual music. His lumigraph played coloured light and is used in a dazzling scene in the sci-fi film The Time Travelers.

start.title: Space Invaders
start.brief_description: Space Invaders is an arcade video game developed by Tomohiro Nishikado and released in 1978. It is one of the earliest shooting games and the aim is to defeat waves of aliens with a laser cannon to earn as many points as possible.

constellations_other.name: Colour and illusion
constellations_other.description: Exploring the science of colour, light, reflection and movement.

end.title: Home Alone
end.creator_credit: John Hughes
end.brief_description: Eight-year-old Kevin McCallister makes the most of the situation after his family unwittingly leaves him behind when they go on Christmas vacation. But when a pair of bungling burglars set their sights on Kevin’s house, the plucky kid stands ready to defend his territory. By planting booby traps galore, adorably mischievous Kevin stands his ground as his frantic mother attempts to race home before Christmas Day.

constellations_other.name: Colour and illusion
constellations_other.description: Exploring the science of colour, light, reflection and movement.

constellations_other.name: Neo-noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

constellations_other.name: Houses that move us
constellations_other.description: Our homes are important to us. When they’re good, they’re our havens. If that home changes, or things go wrong, it can affect us very deeply. This constellation looks at the different ways directors and game devs have positioned the home onscreen - from sanctuary, to hostile enemy.

recommendations.quote: This legendary Christmas film penned by John Hughes is one of the most quotable films in history. But it's not just a screwball kid's comedy about Kevin overcoming his fears, it's equally about maternal devotion and Catherine O'Hara's Kate McAllister quest to reunite with her son.

links.description: This simple adaptation of the game console to produce an unearthly effect can be compared to the use of reflective glass as a practical effect in Home Alone to create the illusion that Harry’s head has been set alight.

links.description: Taree Mackenzie uses a ‘Pepper’s ghost’ technique that employs light, reflection and glass to create a seemingly three-dimensional sculpture. This reflective technique is used in the original Space Invaders console to make the graphics appear against an illuminated moon backdrop.

end.creator_credit: Universal Everything

constellations_other.name: Colour and illusion

links.description: In Hue, the character moves through a grayscale world that can be transformed with colour. Similarly, players control by colours of the characters in Kinfolk by jumping, recreating their kaleidoscopic appearance in a plain white background.

results.name: Fight for your right
results.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

key_work.title: Occupy Wall Street protestors in New York City
key_work.brief_description: In 2011, the connectivity and speed of social media seemed promising for society and democracy. Platforms like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube were integral to mobilising people and coordinating protest movements like Occupy Wall Street, which aims to create greater economic equality.

constellations_primary.name: Fight for your right

start.title: Mr. Robot
start.brief_description: A young programmer, Elliot, suffers from a debilitating anti-social disorder and finds himself in the intersection between the cybersecurity firm he works for and the underworld organisations bringing down corporate America.

constellations_other.name: Hack the planet
constellations_other.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

constellations_other.name: Freedom from surveillance
constellations_other.description: Real world and cinematic authoritarianism and resistance explored through documentaries, Hollywood blockbusters, TV and videogames.

end.title: Riot
end.creator_credit: Joanna Werner and Louise Smith
end.brief_description: A look at the 1970s Gay Rights Movement in Australia through the eyes of dedicated activist Lance Gowland. As Lance deals with his sexuality, he must also juggle work, family and relationships.

constellations_other.name: Fight for your right
constellations_other.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

links.description: While Mr Robot takes a dystopian approach to protest and resistance, Jeffrey Walker’s Riot tells the true story of the fight for LGBTQIA+ rights in Australia, specifically Sydney, where the Mardi Gras was established to fight for rights and showed protesting can be a form of celebration.

video_links.name: The Handmaid's Tale: Series Trailer • A Hulu Original

end.brief_description: Set in a dystopian future, a woman is forced to live as a concubine under a fundamentalist theocratic dictatorship. A TV adaptation of Margaret Atwood’s novel.

constellations_other.name: Directions of storytelling
constellations_other.description: Panoramic slides gave magic lanternists the ability to progress narratives by adjusting slides left or right. This movement is emblematic of a panning shot where the camera follows the action the natural way your head moves.

constellations_other.name: Painting pictures
constellations_other.description: Painter and photographer Louis Le Prince was inspired to develop the technology to make animated pictures by the circular panoramic paintings of his friends. His films captured everyday life and alluded to his artistic vision for cinema.

constellations_other.name: Fight for your right
constellations_other.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

links.description: While real-life protests were used as inspiration for Riot, the opposite exchange happens with The Handmaid’s Tale. The show’s iconic blood red costume and stark white hood have been adopted by real-life protestors, particularly those fighting for reproductive and women’s’ rights in America.

links.description: After 12 years as a correspondent on The Daily Show, Samantha Bee created her own late-night show in 2016, becoming the first woman to host a late-night satire show, which has been critically acclaimed. Aside from skewering political and cultural moments, Bee also uses the show to fight for women’s rights.

links.description: Dun, dun. It didn’t take long for the Law & Order TV franchise to create an episode around a crime at the Occupy Wall St camps. While they prepared the set and created a fake camp nearby the real camp, protestors occupied the set and #mockupy started trending.

links.description: Much of the Occupy Wall St footage captured by news outlets featured the famous Charging Bull statue in Wall St protected by police. This Wall St symbol of inequality also appears in Mr. Robot, when revolutionary hacker Darlen Alderson castrates it. Generally, Mr. Robot shares many of the concerns of the Occupy Movement.
